{"title":"Section 5, Page 3","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"The President announced that the first business in order
•tvas the Reports of Committees.
Mr. 31. 31- Cohe^i rose and stated, in substance, that the Committee of
»hich he had the honor to be Chairman, instructed him to report to the Convention their proceedings from the adjournment in June up to the present
day. He regretted that this report must be verbal, for, as is wefl known to
many of them, and particularly to his esteemed friends, the Secretary, Mr.
Flanders, and Col. Payne, that he (Mr- C.) had devoted to the service of
the road so much of that leisure which he could snatch from the pressing duties
of an arduous profession, that he had not time left to write out the report.
Orally, he would state that, on the 5th of June last, this Convention appointed
a Permanent Committee to procure surveys, the necessary legislation, and the
means of defraying preliminary expenses. The Permanent Committee
assembled on the 5th of June, and appointed a Special Committee to procure
such legislation as might be needed, and an Executive Committee at New
Orleans, to carry out the duties of the Permanent Committee during
the recess.
The first named of these two Committees, to-wit: the Special Committee*
of -which he had the honor to be Chairman, have, with great pains, prepared an elaborate draft of an Act to provide for the organization of corporations: also, a Memorial to the Legislature, &c; an Act to authorize subscriptions to the road, and provide for the payment thereof. This pamphlet, he
said, was now in the hands of all the members of said Special Committee for
examination and revision. He handed in a copy to be preserved among the
records of this Convention.
Mr. Cohen, in continuation, said that the second of these Committees, viz :
the Executive, addressed memorials to the Parochial and Municipal Authorities
w grants of money, proportionate to their interest in the road, and afterwards
sent their ever-prompt, able and faithful agent, Mr. B. H. Payne, into the
^untry to collect the appropriations-
Subsequently, he and other gentlemen were appointed by the Executive
Committee as Delegates to the Burkeville Convention, called by the friends of
th« road in St. Landry.
he Executive Committee', appreciating the wisdom of the steps taken by
. Cltizens of St. Landry, and the importance of establishing intimate relations
-Lexas, seconded and supported it to the extent of their ability and influ-
■ The objects of that Convention were fully accomplished, and Texas and
msiana there engaged to carry forward, in unison and harmony, those great
easures destined to produce incalculable advantages to both States. The
aT>Ks of the Committee were tendered to their Delegates, for the faithful
